data.title: Sly & Robbie
data.meta_description: Explore the Red Bull Music Academy archive, tracing the global music institutionâs more than 20-year history
data.text:
Sly Dunbar

Itâs great to be here in Barcelona.

Benji B

I feel super-privileged to be doing this because we have with us the most famous drum and bass section of all time. Please join me in welcoming Sly & Robbie. [applause] I believe itâs right to say that since you started working together in 1975 that youâve played on over 50,000 records. Is that right?

Robbie Shakespeare

Some say 200,000, some say one million. But I hope it reaches two million, probably three.

Benji B

I did read one estimate that says if you count every use of every rhythm youâve ever played on, then itâs not unfeasible that itâs over 200,000, which officially makes you the most prolific recording artists of all time. I think thatâs worth a round of applause as well [applause].

Robbie Shakespeare

Thank the world, thank the world.

Benji B

So, weâre all music fans in this room, and I think itâs fair to say that everyone here has a record youâve played on, even if they donât know it. So can you run down a few of the names of the people whose records youâve played on, both in Jamaica and internationally?

Sly Dunbar

From the Jamaican side weâve probably worked with everyone â Bob Marley, Dennis Brown, Gregory Isaacs, Mighty Diamonds, Toots & the Maytals, Jimmy Cliff, Peter Tosh, Bunny Wailer, Nambo Robinson [laughs and points]. Everybody. Cultureâ¦ I could go on and on and on. On the international market, weâve worked with James Brown, Carly Simon, Nona Hendryx, No Doubt, Joe Cocker, Bob Dylan, Rolling Stones, Herbie Hancock, Grace Jones, Gwen Guthrie, Ian Dury, Simply Red, Serge Gainsbourg. From Brazil, there was this girl we did a song with that went to No 1, the one with Ben Harper singing on itâ¦ I canât remember. Probably, when Iâve finished Iâll remember and bring it up.

Benji B

Thatâs just a rough idea of all the ground weâve got to cover in the next 90 minutes or so. But one question I often wonder about with you guys is that in 1975 you were already such established musicians in your own rightâ¦ what made you gravitate to each other and collaborate?

Sly Dunbar

It was like magic, I always say. When we were kids in Jamaica we used to go to a place called Idlers Rest, which is downtown. All the musicians used to go there to look for work, everyone knows you, itâs where you go to look for session work. I used to see Robbie there sometimes and weâd talk, but I used to play in a club on Red Hill Road â in Kingston, we called it called Las Vegas. Robbie was playing in this club, too, so when I got a break Iâd go and listen to his band and when he got a break heâd listen to my band. There were a lot of songs he was playing on for Bunny Lee & the Aggrovators, and I asked him if some of these were songs that he was playing on, because we used to play some on the bandstand. And he said, âYes.â We started talking and one day we were in Idlers Rest and I asked him to drop me by Channel One because I thought there was a session, and I told him to check back with me the next day because there might be some session work. We used to control the sessions, so he came and checked me. But the first session we really played on was a session that Bunny Lee and Robbie organized together and he told me to play, I think it was a John Holt song called âI Forgot To Say I Love Youâ.

I think it was a John Holt session, but that was the first one I played on.

Benji B

You mentioned Channel One and the Aggrovators. Can you explain to people who arenât familiar with them what they are?

Sly Dunbar

Channel One is a recording studio, one of the best in Jamaica. And this is where Robbie and I got this great break in life because the owner of the studio loved bass and drums and took great pleasure in presenting it right. Weâd be there all the time recording, and before they got the sound, we sort of brought the sound to them and it took us two years to really get it where we wanted it. For us, thatâs our template that brought us to the international work.

Benji B

Can you explain the scene of the big backing bands like the Aggrovators and the Revolutionaries?

Sly Dunbar

Iâm going to let Robbie explain the Aggrovators.

Robbie Shakespeare

The Aggrovators was a studio backing band, Bunny Lee named it. It was Santa on drums, Chinna on guitar, Bernard âTouterâ Harvey or Tyrone Downie on keyboards, it depends. But the main ones were me, Santa and Chinna.

Benji B

And what period are we talking about?

Robbie Shakespeare

Some Slim Smith, Delroy Wilson, Johnny Clarke, Cornel Campbell.

Benji B

So this was the early â70s.

Robbie Shakespeare

Yes. I was the one whoâd show Johnny Clarke into the studio saying to give him a chance. He used to be there every day begging, âPlease, please, I can sing.â Iâd say, âMove, studio idler.â We used to call him âstudio idlerâ before we called him by his right name, Johnny Clarke. But I said, âGive the youth a chance, letâs hear him sing.â I said to him, âDonât let me down, or Iâll run you out myself.â We went in the studio and the first song came out, and it was, âWhoa, he can sing!â So, I started guiding him through his career.

Benji B

So, youâre responsible for putting him on the map?

Robbie Shakespeare

Yeah, a little bit.

Benji B

Were you involved in a backing band too?

Sly Dunbar

Yeah, I was involved in the Revolutionaries. We used to have a studio in Waterhouse, where a friend of mine had a soundsystem, and weâd go there and listen to all these foreign songs. We sat there and said if we can get this drum sound into reggae weâd be onto something. I went to Channel One studio and met Ernest [Ranglin], and we were talking about drum sounds and I was playing Philadelphia International records, one of my favorite labels. I said, âIf we can get the drum sound something like this, it would work.â It took us two years to get close and start recording songs like âM.P.L.A.â, âI Need a Roofâ for Mighty Diamonds and a couple of others. And the sound broke out and everyone was trying to get to Channel One because they liked the sound. We stayed there for a while until the studio closed down and we had to take up places in other studios. And we started doing our own production in Channel One.

Benji B

Itâs often documented, the rivalry between labels. Was there rivalry between bands too?

Sly Dunbar

No, we all looked out for one another. It was the labels who were fighting, not the musicians.

Benji B

And Robbie, how did you first hear Slyâs drumming?

Robbie Shakespeare

He used to play in Skin, Flesh & Bones on Tit For Tat [records]. During the time of recording, that was my main source of getting a little bread. At night he played in a band called Big Relation. There was a club near where Sly played on Red Hill Road called Evil People where the Fab 5 were resident. But the Fab 5 and the owner of the club had a falling out, so they called the owner of the band I was playing in to fill that post. Touter, who was in Inner Circle, said, âLetâs go over Tit For Tat to check Sly.â I said, âWhoâs Sly?â âSlyâs a drummer.â âAlright, come on.â We went over there and Sly is sitting down on the drums, and I said, âWhoa, he can beat a drum. Thatâs a good sound, I want a session with that youth.â So, the next morning I told Bunny [âStrikerâ] Lee, âStriker, I found a wicked drummer, I want to use him on a session. Book the time.â So, I called Sly and we started playing and everyone was jumping, âWhoa yeah!â The studio was packed, and they said, âYeah, that combination is wicked.â It started from there.

Benji B

And you both knew the first time you played together.

Robbie Shakespeare

Yeah, I was putting a band together for Peter Tosh, Word, Sound & Power, and he said, âIs Sly coming?â I said, âYeah.â

Benji B

And you toured quite heavily with Peter Tosh.

Robbie Shakespeare:

Yes, we toured a lot. Peter was Word, me and Sly were Sound & Power.

Benji B

Before you got involved in the Aggrovators, did you have a mentor, someone you studied to learn bass?

Robbie Shakespeare

Aggrovators werenât the first studio thing. They were always in the studio, but I played with Joe Gibbs, the regular record people, Lee âScratchâ Perry. Sometimes as individuals weâd play for other people. Family Man was the main man for me who first played bass and made it sound nice. So I learned off him.

Benji B

Which band was he from?

Robbie Shakespeare

Aston âFamily Manâ Barrett is now playing with The Wailers and was Bob Marleyâs bass player for years and years. But at the time he was in the Hippy Boys, rehearsing. You donât know about Family Man? You know, they say heâs bad [laughs].

Benji B

And what about you Sly, who was your mentor?

Sly Dunbar

My mentor was the drummer for the Skatalites, Lloyd Knibbs. And I used to listen a lot to the drummer for Booker T & the MGâs, Al Jackson, and a lot of Philadelphia. And there are other drummers in Jamaica, like Santa and Carly from The Wailers, Winston Grennan, Paul Douglas, Mikey âBooâ [Richards]. I respect all these drummers and have learnt a lot from them. From them, I listened and created my own style. They played some things I copied. Other things I recreated.

Benji B

And who gave you your nickname?

Sly Dunbar

I was in a band called the Volcanos for three months in a Jamaican hotel. I used to listen to a lot of Sly & the Family Stone, still do, and the bandleader said, âAnything but Sly, Sly, Sly?â âNo, Slyâs the boss.â So everything I did, they called me Sly. When I came back to town it stuck.

Benji B

So apart from Sly Stone, what were the biggest influences from outside of Jamaica?

Sly Dunbar

A lot of Motown, James Brown, Stax, the Beatles.

Benji B

There seems to be a tradition of covering US R&B songs in Jamaica.

Robbie Shakespeare

Jamaica is a place that loves a great music, so if we can do a good cover version of a song, we go for it. Songs like Randy Newmanâs âBaltimore,â [which was covered by the Tamlins]â¦ I always enjoyed that song. Not just us, but other producers would cover a lot of songs, anything they can make a good version out of.

Benji B

How did your style change when you became producers yourselves?

Sly Dunbar

We became producers because the radio was paying all these recordings for the producers and they were hitting. I looked down and said to Robbie, âWhatâs the future for us? Weâre not owning ourselves on tape, producers are.â So, Robbie said, âI think we should try to own our own material, but weâre not going to stop doing sessions. Weâll play every day.â So, we started doing songs.

Robbie Shakespeare

Hold on. Even before we were producing ourselves, we were producing other people, not knowing we were producing. When we were in the studio weâd arrange the song for them, âThis sounds good and that sounds goodâ¦ Singer, sing this song instead of that one.â Weâd arrange and produce, not knowing we were producing for the producer. Because the man who says heâs the producer is around the back, he canât do anything. Weâd say, âReady now!,â and heâd tell the engineer, âTake it!â, and then heâd say, âHowâs that sound, Robbie? Howâs that sound, Sly?â And weâd go around and listen and tell him. So, when we got really serious, sometimes weâd play a rhythm for a singer and heâd say, âI donât like it.â âNo, man, thatâs perfect.â âI donât like it.â OK, weâll take that for ourselves. So, the ones that people rejected, we recorded them ourselves. Your turn, Sly.

Sly Dunbar

Picking up, we started doing our own stuff and none of the singers wanted to sign for us because we were just two little musicians. Robbie called up Gregory [Isaacs] because they were good friends. He came and sang six songs in a day, and the next day he came in to voice, and he got there before us. And one of the songs that came out of that session was our first No 1 in Jamaica, called âSoon Forward.â To this day, Gregory and us are good friends. If weâre doing a stage show in Jamaica, no one can go on before him â he wants to open the concert and then go home. We started owning our stuff and Chris Blackwell from Island Recordsâ¦ we just want to do stuff for the people, follow in the footsteps of Coxsone or Berry Gordy, and he took us up and wanted to work with us and we started working with him, producing Black Uhuru, Ini Kamoze, all those people. But what we had in mind was forming a young Motown in Jamaica, weâre still aiming at that.

Benji B

Tell me about your work with Black Uhuru.

Sly Dunbar

Michael Rose was a friend of mine, we grew up together, his brother and I were good friends. He was a singer, too, but before that Michael was a DJ. I was trying to help him get in the production business, but his brother died in a car accident. Michael came to see me and told me that. I told him we were down at Channel One every day and to come down and check me, so he came down and we talked. He left and came back with some people and said, âThis is Duckie and Puma and we have a group called Black Uhuru.â We started trying some songs, doing a version of âNo No No,â a Wailers song called âLet Him Goâ and âSun Is Shining.â And I said to him, âWe can cut some original songs because everyone likes the sound.â The first songs we recorded were âGuess Whoâs Coming to Dinnerâ, âShine Eye Galâ â we did six songs that day â âPlastic Smileâ. The first one that came out was âGeneral Penitentiaryâ. Before it came out, we had no money to release them, so we cut them on dubplate and gave them to the great U-Roy, who had a soundsystem. I canât remember the name of it, but it was the No1 soundsystem. So I said to him, âWeâll give you these four records.â He played them for one year before any of them were released. When anyoneâs going to the dance theyâd go there, because no one else had them and he wouldnât play them before 1 o'clock. So thatâs how we got started.

Benji B

Which shall we play, âShine Eye Galâ or âGeneral Penitentiaryâ?

Sly Dunbar

âShine Eye" is bad.

(music: [Black Uhuru â âShine Eye Galâ / applause)

Robbie Shakespeare

[Referring to playing instruments on stage] Thank you, that was a stage version.

Sly Dunbar

Recorded very differently, because it was originally done in 1976, so we have to update it.

Robbie Shakespeare

Keith Richards was playing guitar on it, heâs the one going [makes aggressive guitar sound].

Benji B

How did you first hook up with [the Rolling Stones]?

Robbie Shakespeare

Mick Jagger and Keith Richards came to Jamaica for the Peace Concert. They wanted to sign a reggae act, so when they saw Peter [Tosh], they were interested in him. Peter, myself and Herbie Miller were invited to New York to discuss the contract. We went in there and talk, talk, talk and it was a done deal. We went on tour with them. What year was that, Sly? The Some Girls tour.

Sly Dunbar

It was 1978.

Robbie Shakespeare

Me and Keith were tight, like Sly & Robbie. And the drummer Charlie Watts, also tight, like Sly & Robbie. Keith used to come to Jamaica. He has a house in Jamaica now, but he used to be at my house regularly. One time, he came in and heard us record and said, âCan I play?â I said, âYeah, man.â So, he went to his car and pulled out his guitar, came in and played. We did two tracks that day.

Sly Dunbar

âDirty Harry.â

Benji B

What was touring with the Rolling Stones like?

Robbie Shakespeare

Something youâve never experienced before, totally different. There used to be four, five, six bands playing. But when the Rolling Stones came into the compound, everyone else would go to their dressing room. You couldnât walk around, these big security would come around, [affects deep voice] âThe Stones are coming.â But theyâd say, âOh, the Rastasâ¦ Theyâre OK, theyâre good.â Because Mick and Keith and Charlie would say, âWhereâs Sly, whereâs Robbie?â Theyâd come to our dressing room before going to their own, and weâd play cards and joke.

Benji B

And your musical collaboration with Mick Jagger went on quite a while, right?

Robbie Shakespeare

Yeah, we produced an album with Peter Tosh and we invited him on there to do a song. And he did âWalk and Donât Look Backâ. When Peter was on tour heâd sneak on to perform it with him. But we were tight like that. Even when we did our album that won a Grammy, Friends, we asked Keith to play guitar and he did, because we did, [sings] âI canât get no satisfaction.â Mick was busy, couldnât get to sing it. That would've been good, we wanted him to sing it.

Benji B

Despite being so busy with all your work on the international scene, touring with the Rolling Stones around the world, you always made time to release stuff in Jamaica, which has its own unique recording industry as well. Itâs remarkable that you managed to balance both. How did you do it?

Robbie Shakespeare

They used to say Sly & Robbie must take drugs [laughs]. We used to be in the studio from about 10am, and a lot of the time weâd rehearse until about 7 or 8pm. When we were touring, most of the time weâd come straight from the studio. Finish playing, go home, sleep; the next morning weâre back in the studio, just keeping it going. Now weâve slowed down a bit, we plan it better. We record a lot of songs, check the tape back and then and say, âHmm, that song will work on that.â Thereâs always music there to work on. We know we can call the engineer, and say, âSet that up, weâre coming in.â Much easier now than then.

Benji B

Your dedication to Jamaica at the time is demonstrated by starting Taxi Records, which canât have been easy with everything else going on. Why did you start it?

Robbie Shakespeare

I had a label called Bar Bells. Sly had Taxi, so we stuck with that. Sly used to come to the studio in a taxi with a little driver we called Shorty. We used to get a lot of fun with Sly and that driverâ¦ He was a ton of fun, so as soon as Sly said he was starting a label, we said, âYeah, Taxi.â So we stuck with that because it was a fun thing. Shorty. [laughs]

Sly Dunbar

One day we were going to the Sunsplashâ¦ Shorty had his car, taking him, me and a friend of his daughter, to Montego Bay and the car ran out of water. We had to get out and push, then go and perform. But it was fun [laughs]. We had to put water in the radiator, start it and jump in, Kingston-bound. Weâd laugh and say, âTomorrow, back to the studio.â But weâd spend days in the studio, more time there than at home.

Benji B

So, thatâs where the name Taxi comes from.

Sly Dunbar

I used to take it late at night, when I finished âTit for Tatâ he would be out there to take me to the studio. I never bought a car so I had to take a taxi. He owned a car, I bought it for him, so I just said, âTake me to the studio, and you can do anything you want to do.â

Benji B

Who were the artists that you put out on that label over the years?

Sly Dunbar

Gregory Isaacs, Black Uhuru, Jimmy Riley, the Tamlins, Ini Kamoze, Junior Delgado, Dennis Brown, a guy who used to sing in the Chi-Lites and the band itself, the Taxi Gang, with Nambo, Dean Fraser, Robbie Lyn, and all these people.

Benji B

How did you get the money together? Thatâs not easy, starting your own label.

Sly Dunbar

When we were touring with Peter and the Rolling Stones we were getting $100 a week, but our lunch money was $240.

Benji B

So they gave you $100 for the week but $240 for lunch? OK [laughs].

Sly Dunbar

So me and Robbie came up with a plan to come away with some money. I had this friend called Gary and Iâd tell him to get a rubbish bag and go in after breakfast and pick up all the boiled eggs and bread, sling the bag over his shoulder and take it on the bus. When we were touring with the Stones weâd take jerk chicken and use that as our food, that and juices. So we saved the money and took it back to Jamaica. I bought a pair of Syndrums for $500, and some tape, a ticket back to Jamaica and out of the money we booked Channel One studio for a week. And out of that came âBaltimoreâ and some Black Uhuru stuff. We did a Black Uhuru album from it called Sinsemilla, and Chris Blackwell signed them from that.

Robbie Shakespeare

The first thing with Black Uhuru was Showcase.

Sly Dunbar

We did that the same time as the songs we gave to U-Roy.

Robbie Shakespeare

We couldnât put it out for about a year because we didnât have enough money, everything was on tape.

Benji B

So itâs fair to say Taxi was founded on lunch money [laughter] .

Sly Dunbar

Yeah, thatâs cool. Garbage bag money. Lunch money. Garbage bag sounds more roots, yeah?

Benji B

So how did you first meet Chris Blackwell?

Sly Dunbar

Ijahman Levi said his boss wants to meet us. âHis boss, whoâs his boss?â So one night I went by the Hilton Hotel and Ijahman was there and he said, âCome on and meet the boss.â It was Chris Blackwell. I said, âOh wicked,â and thatâs how I got to meet him.

Robbie Shakespeare

The first time I met him was through a movie star named Esther Anderson. She came for me and said Chris Blackwell wants to meet me. I said, âWhoâs Chris Blackwell?â She said, âBob Marleyâs boss.â He wanted to know who the man who played bass on âConcrete Jungleâ was. âOh, you played bass? Nice.â That was it. Years went by, and Chris knows about Sly & Robbie. Virgin signed that thing with Sly and he look vexed, he wanted Sly & Robbie. But he let us play with Grace Jones, and that was his way of getting us into his camp. I was a Compass Point All Star, and then he signed Sly & Robbieâ¦

Sly Dunbar

That was in 1980. He came to Jamaica and Robbie signed a contract and the rest is history. When he asked us to do the Grace Jones record, he called us up to his New York apartment and played some Grace Jones stuff to us, and gave us an album, which to this day I havenât listened to it. He called and said weâre going to Nassau to record. When we got there, Robbie said, âWhat are we going to do?â Nobody knows, so Chris said he was going to make some music, but they were thinking of rehearsing and then going into to the studio. Robbie said, âNo, go into the studio and record everything we rehearse.â So, we did that with the engineer and co-producer Alex Sadkin. One day for drums, one day for bass, one day for guitar. I remember the first tune recorded was âWarm Leatherette,â and I heard it played back and âWow!â Then, the second one was âPrivate Life,â one of my favorite records.

Benji B

And thereâs a serious dub version. Can I play that?

Sly Dunbar

Yeah.

Benji B

When was it recorded?

Sly Dunbar

1980.

(music: Grace Jones â âPull Up to the Bumperâ / applause)

Benji B

I was lucky enough to interview Wally Badarou at the Red Bull Music Academy in Melbourne and he told us some amazing stories about that era, including the time you were working with James Brown. [Laughter] He skimmed around it and suggested what the vibe was, but maybe you can tell us what that was like?

Sly Dunbar

It was nice. James Brown was his typical self, soul brother. I think Al Sharpton was his hairdresser at the time.

Benji B

Al Sharpton was his hairdresser!

Sly Dunbar

[Laughs] In Nassau the studio would be over here, and over there is the ocean. Al Sharpton would do his hair before he got to the studio and when he came in, it was like he was performing. He called Mikey âMontego.â We played two songs for him. It was great, we learnt a lot, I look up to him, heâs the Godfather.

Benji B

But whatâs the working process? Heâs regimented, I imagine youâre too individual for him.

Sly Dunbar

No, we wrote a song and wanted him to sing it. He was saying Robbie and myself should sing it and he would go [does James Brown scream]. We said, âNo, James, we want you to sing it.â But I saw the record at Island Records some time later, and the flipside was one of the songs weâd played for him. I think Chris Blackwell gave him the multitrack tape and he put it out.

Benji B

So who were some of the other artists who passed through while you were there?

Sly Dunbar

Iron Maiden. We did Mick Jaggerâs solo album at that time.

Benji B

And how much influence was the early-â80s New York disco thing having on reggae?

Sly Dunbar

We used to listen to it because it was happening, but I listened more to Philadelphia because thatâs where disco came from. But what we did was transform anything we heard into reggae. âBuckingham Palace,â Peter Tosh, came off like disco. But it was a pattern that Robbie and myself had used for a long time, we did it on âSun is Shiningâ for Black Uhuru and on an album called Rasta Fiesta. We were in the studio and Robbie said, âPlay that beat again.â We put the drum and bass down and Peter came up with the lyrics.

Benji B

Back in Jamaica in the mid-â80s, things were going a bit digital. Can you explain about the Syndrums, because you were one of the first to use them. The Simmons drums first?

Sly Dunbar

It was the Syndrum first. I got one â two little Caribbean musicians â and we brought it home to experiment. But then again, I saw an advertisement for Simmons, so I ordered one, a red, green and gold one. But then I canceled it because I didnât know what I was buying. I think Boy George and Culture Club bought it. I said, âReally? Now Iâve got to get it.â So, I went and bought another one for when we were cutting the Black Uhuru Anthem album. They sent it down to Nassau. The first time I played it on a record was the Rolling Stonesâ Too Much Blood album, thereâs a track where I did a snare with the Simmons for the first time. Mick said, âCome and overdub this.â So I went and overdubbed it. I knew it was going to be the age of electronics, so I started getting into it. I used a Simmons on the Anthem album and a couple of records in Jamaica. A lot of people even now in Jamaica ask me for the Simmons, they want to hear that sound again. So Iâve acquired a DD-20 Roland kit, which Iâm going to start using in the studio. People want to hear something fresh again, cool it off, go back to the real acoustic stuff again. But electronics is good. Analog is also good.

Benji B

Then you started incorporating an MPC into your work.

Sly Dunbar

The first person in Jamaica to have one was Robbie Lyn, the keyboard player, and I borrowed his for a Black Uhuru tune âSomebodyâs Watching You.â Then I bought one for myself. I always had a drum machine but most Jamaican drummers were scared of them. I said, âWhy?â I started programming everything, I bought an MPC, a DMX, I bought the SP-1200, I have now the [MPC] 500, I have all the machines. I just want to make beats and itâs cool to sit and program something youâre feeling. But most drummers wonât program anything. Out of all of them, Iâm the only one whoâll program.
